msDesc.head: Text on royal governance, and pseudo-Augustine, De XII abusiuis saeculi (excerpt)

summary.seg: Cambridge, Corpus Christi College MS 412 (hereafter CCCC MS 412) came to Corpus Christi College Cambridge as part of the donation of printed books and manuscripts made in 1574 by Matthew Parker (1504-1575) Parker, Matthew, 1504-1575, archbishop of Canterbury. The core part of CCCC MS 412 comprises 77 leaves (ff. 1r-77v) of instructional Latin literature. Folios 1r-77r bear a copy of an anonymous text sometimes attributed to Durand de Champagne known as De informatione principum. This is followed on ff. 77r-77v by a short extract from pseudo-Augustine's De duodecim abusionum gradibus known as De XII abusiuis saeculi. CCCC MS 412 is a composite volume and it is possible that folios i-iv and v-viii were already bound with folios 1-77 at the time of Parker's gift to Corpus Christi College, since a partially erased medieval signiature with a distinctive flourish on f. viii recto also appears in simplified form on f. 77v. However, the signator is unidentified and undated and so this may reflect a change to the structure of the volume that postdates Parker's donation.

The first four medieval endleaves in the volume (ff. i-iv) contain the Articuli Cleri enacted in 1316, followed by some brief legal notes on f. iv verso; both were copied in the same hand and the legal notes are signed by an Edmund Poplay, who mentioned a connection to an unspecified university ('studia quindecim annorum que habuit in hac uniuersitate in facultate arcium') and recorded the date of a legal action as 12 June 1489 ('Hec gracia concessa et confirmata est anno domini millesimo cccco lxxxxix mensia Jun. xiimo'). The biographical information that Poplay recorded in his notes on f. iv verso allows him to be identified as the Edmund Poplay (Popley) of the Diocese of York, who was ordained as a deacon in 1484 and was Principal of Beef Hall in Oxford c. 1496-1497. There is no codicological evidence for or against the union of Parts 1 and 2 in 1489 (Poplay's notes in Part 1 and De informatione principum in Part 2), so it is not possible to determine if Poplay was the owner of ff. 1r-77v, or if their composite arrangement occured later.

Dr Sarah Gilbert
Project Cataloguer
Curious Cures Project, Cambridge University Library

foliation.p: Foliated as: a-b + i-iv | 1-77 | v-viii + c-d
foliation.note: Foliated in pencil in Hindu-Arabic numerals in the upper outer corner of each recto.

collation.p:
Quires of 8 leaves for the most part, arranged as follows:
Four endleaves (ff. i recto - iv verso)
Quires 1-98 (ff. 1-72)
Quire 108-3 (ff. 73-77; 6th-8th leaves cancelled)
Four endleaves (ff. v recto - viii verso)

signatures.p: No leaf signatures common to the entire volume.
No quire signatures common to the entire volume.

catchwords.seg: No catchwords common to the entire volume.

binding.p: 18th century binding. Quarter bound in leather with parchment sides over paste- or millboard. Five raised bands on spine (not photographed); spine is unlabelled and undecorated. Paper pastedowns pasted over the turn ins. Several other manuscripts at Corpus Christi College are bound in this style and with these materials, e.g., Â Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 456, so it is likely that the College undertook a rebinding programme in the 18th century, perhaps focussing on the most fragile or poorly bound items in the manuscript collection at that time.

Two paper endleaves at each end of the volume, probably contemporary with the binding, ff. a - b and c - d. Folio a recto contains a 'Corpus Christi College, Cambridge' stamp in black ink, and the shelfmark 'MS 412' written in black ink; all other paper endleaves are blank.
The binding is tight in the latter half of the volume which impedes the maximum angle of opening for the book.

provenance.p: Folios i-iv written and owned by Edmund Popley Popley, Edmund of the Diocese of York and Principal of Beef Hall in Oxford, c. 1496-1497. Popley may also have owned ff. 1r-77v, which would explain how his notes came to be bound with the rest of the volume, but there is no strong evidence to rule for or against Popley's ownership of ff. 1r-77v.

The first four medieval endleaves in the volume (ff. i-iv) are in Popley's hand and contain a copy of the Articuli Cleri enacted in 1316 (ff. ii recto - iv verso), followed by some brief legal notes (f. iv verso). Popley signed the notes on f. iv verso as 'Edmundus Poplay' and mentioned a connection to an unspecified university ('studia quindecim annorum que habuit in hac uniuersitate in facultate arcium') and recorded the date of a legal action as 12 June 1489 ('Hec gracia concessa et confirmata est anno domini millesimo cccco lxxxxix mensia Jun. xiimo'). The name, the date, and the long connection to a university allows for the Poplay of ff. i-iv to be identified as the Edmund Poplay (Popley) of the Diocese of York, who was ordained as a deacon in 1484 and was Principal of Beef Hall in Oxford c. 1496-1497. There is no codicological evidence for or against the union of Parts 1 (ff. i-iv) and 2 (ff. 1r-77v) in 1489 , so it is not possible to determine if Poplay was the owner of ff. 1r-77v, or if their composite arrangement occured later, but Poplay's ownership of ff. 1r-77v offers the simplest explanation for how his notes came to be with the main section of MS 412.

Full transcription of Poplay's note on f. iv verso: 'Litera domini regis iusticiariis directa supra ponitur infra constituciones prouinciales de foro competenti C circumspecte agatis in quo C continentur omnes casus in quibus iudex ecclesiasticus cognoscere potest regia prohibitione non obstante . Melius tamen est quod non faciat nisi regiam consultacionem optineat etc. Edmundus poplay. Supplicat venerabili etc. Edmundus poplay in jure canonico Baccallarius quatenus studia quindecim annorum que habuit in hac uniuersitate in facultate arcium et in juribus Ciuili et canonico sibi sufficiant ad hunc effectum ut admittatur ad incipiendum in jure canonico ita quod soluat markam . Hec gracia concessa et confirmata est anno domini millesimo cccco lxxxxix mensia Jun. xiimo condicio talis est quod soluat uniuersitati xls'.

William Porter Porter, William : name written in large gothic letters on f. i verso, probably in the 16th century, and presumably indicating his possession of the manuscript. No William Porter with plausible biographical information has been identified. M.R. James noted in his Catalogue that a William Porter also signed his name in Cambridge, Trinity College, MS B.16.3, front flyleaf 3r , but as both the script and the spelling ('Willyam Porter') are different, it is not necessarily the case that these are the same William Porter.

listBibl.bibl: M. R. James, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Manuscripts in Corpus Christi College, Cambridge, 2 vols (1912), Vol. II, no. 412

acquisition.p: Folios 77v given to Corpus Christi College in 1574 by Matthew Parker (1504-1575) Parker, Matthew, 1504-1575, archbishop of Canterbury. It is possible that folios i-iv and v-viii were already bound with folios 1-77 at the time of Parker's gift to Corpus Christi College, particularly as a partially erased signiature with a distinctive flourish on f. viii recto also appears in simplified form on f. 77v, although unfortunately the name of the signator cannot be identified in either case. All Parts bound together c. 1722 as f. ii recto bears a siglum 'N. 26' assigned to the volume in Thomas Stanley's Catalogue of 1722.

recordHist.source: This catalogue record draws on M. R. James, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Manuscripts in Corpus Christi College, Cambridge, 2 vols (1912), Vol. II, no. 412. Images and a description of the manuscript are also available on the Parker Library website: Parker on the Web: Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 412.

availability.p: Visitors to Corpus Christi College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Parker Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Parker Library: Information for Readers.

listBibl.bibl: For a bibliography for this item maintained by Corpus Christi College Cambridge see: Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 412: Zotero Bibliography

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 412, ff. i-iv

msItem.title: Copy of the Articuli Cleri of King Edward II
msItem.rubric: ii recto Casus in quibus iudex ecclesiasticus potest cognoscere regea prohibicione non obstante concessi per regia magnam cartam
msItem.incipit: ii recto Edwardus dei gratia . Rex anglie et ffrancie et dominus hibernie . Dux acquietanie . Omnibus ad quos presentes litteras pervenerint salutem . Sciatis quod cum dudum temporibus progenitorum nostrorum quondam regum Anglie
msItem.explicit: iv verso ecclesiasticam excercent iuxta tenorem responsionum predictarum absque occasione inquietatione impedimento nostri uel heredum nostrorum seu ministrorum nostrorum quorumcumque
msItem.finalRubric: iv verso teste me ipso apud Eboracum xxiii die mensis nouembris ano regni nostri xiiio

note.p: The Articuli Cleri were enacted on the 24th November 1316, in the reign of King Edward II. The date given here in the CCCC MS 412 copy of the Articuli Cleri is 23 November 1316.

The Articuli Cleri were copied by Edmund Poplay who was Principal of Beef Hall in Oxford, c. 1496-1497; see Provenance for further information on Poplay. Poplay also wrote a note under the Articuli Cleri in which he included biographical information: 'Litera domini regis iusticiariis directa supra ponitur infra constituciones prouinciales de foro competenti C circumspecte agatis in quo C continentur omnes casus in quibus iudex ecclesiasticus cognoscere potest regia prohibitione non obstante . Melius tamen est quod non faciat nisi regiam consultacionem optineat etc. Edmundus poplay. Supplicat venerabili etc. Edmundus poplay in jure canonico Baccallarius quatenus studia quindecim annorum que habuit in hac uniuersitate in facultate arcium et in juribus Ciuili et canonico sibi sufficiant ad hunc effectum ut admittatur ad incipiendum in jure canonico ita quod soluat markam . Hec gracia concessa et confirmata est anno domini millesimo cccco lxxxxix mensia Jun. xiimo condicio talis est quod soluat uniuersitati xls'. The note is written in two different inks, the first ink a visual match for the rest of the Articuli Cleri, and the second ink, which begins at 'Supplicat venerabili etc ...' is darker and more opaque than the ink used for the writing in the rest of this Part.

listBibl.bibl: Emden, BRUO to A.D. 1500, Vol. 3, 'Edmund Popley'

support.material: Parchment, with significant natural flaws on ff. i-ii.

collation.p: Four endleaves (ff. i recto - iv verso)

signatures.p: No leaf signatures particular to this Part.
No quire signatures particular to this Part.

catchwords.seg: No catchwords particular to this Part.

supportDesc.condition: In good condition. Folio i has one large hole, and several smaller holes due to natural defects in the parchment. Adhesive residue on f. i recto, suggestive of former use as a pastedown.

p.seg: Frame-ruling visible in crayon on f. iii verso, no other ruling visible in this Part. Written in single-column format, typically 30 lines to a page, but somewhat informally written, particularly on f. iv verso

handNote.p: Folios ii recto - iv verso written in a secretary hand by Edmund Popley.
The name 'William Porter' written in a textualis 'formata' on f. i verso.

decoNote.p: No significant decoration in this Part.

origin.origDate: Written at the end of the 15th century or in the 16th century, possibly in 1499.
origin.note: Written in England at the end of the 15th century or in the early-16th century. Place of production assigned based on palaeographical and textual information. Date of production can probably be assigned to '1499' based on a dating clause in the document, although it is possible that this is a slightly later copy of an existing document made in 1499.

provenance.p: Written by an Edmund Popley Popley, Edmund . Popley copied the document on ff. ii recto - iv verso and added a dating clause 'Hec gracia concessa et confirmata est a. d. millesimo cccco lxxxxix mens. Iun. xiimo', i.e., 12 June 1499. An Edmund Popley of the correct age to be participating in legal proceedings in 1499 has not been identified.
Owned by a William Porter Porter, William . Porter added his name in large textualis formata letters to f. i verso. No further biographical information is known about him.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 412, ff. 1r-77v
msIdentifier.msName: Part 2 - Text on royal governance, and pseudo-Augustine, De XII abusiuis saeculi (excerpt)

msItem.title: Prologue to the Liber de informatione principum
msItem.incipit: 1r Regnabit rex et sapiens erit et faciet iudicium et iustitiam in terra
msItem.explicit: 1v opulentia diuitiarum temperalium affluentia deliciarum corporalium .

note.p: Followed by a descriptive contents list with 33 numbered chapters.

msItem.title: Main text of De informatione principum
msItem.incipit: 1v Circa primum consideranda est primo dignitas regie magestatis Sciendum est autem quod cum res publica . sit quasi quoddam corpus compaginatum ex membris variis, rex uel princeps in eo obtinet locum capitis . senescali prepositi et iudices officium aurium et oculorum
msItem.explicit: 77r largiri dignetur misericors deus qui in trinitate perfecta viuit et regnat per infinita seculorum secula . Amen

note.p: This text was incorrectly described by M. R. James in his Catalogue as Giles of Rome's De regimine principium. The text is in fact De informatione principum, a text often attributed to Durand de Champagne Durand de Champagne , and which appears in two main recensions, one with an explicit dedication to the future King Louis X of France (b. 4 October 1289; d. 5 June 1316; r. 29 November 1314 â 5 June 1316), and one without the direct address to the future King Louis X. The version of De informatione principum in CCCC MS 412 lacks the explicit dedication to the future King Louis X.
This text also appears in the following manuscripts: Oxford, Balliol College, MS 123 London, British Library, MS Royal 12.B.xviii London, British Library, MS Royal 12.D.xv

listBibl.bibl: Discussion (of the text, not the MS) in L. Delisle, 'Auteur Du Liber De Informatione Principum', Histoire littÃ©raire de la France 31 (1893), pp. 35-47

msItem.title: De XII abusiuis saeculi (excerpt from De duodecim abusionum gradibus)
msItem.author: pseudo-Augustine
msItem.rubric: 77r Que pertineant ad bonum principem ostendit cyprianus in libro de xii . abusionibus seculi Hiis Verbis
msItem.incipit: 77r Iusticia regis est neminem iniuste per potenciam opprimere
msItem.explicit: 77v Ideo anima temporalia amans , indigna est dei amore

note.p: This text is also often attributed to pseudo-Cyprian (Saint), Bishop of Carthage Cyprian, Saint, Bishop of Carthage, pseudo .
Also in Cambridge, Pembroke College, MS 111, f. 131r (see Thomson), and apparently also in Cambridge, Clare College, MS 14, f. 96v.

listBibl.bibl: R. M. Thomson, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts of Pembroke College Cambridge (2022), no. 111, p. 68
H. Walther, Initia carminum ac versuum medii aevi posterioris latinorum, Carmina medii aevi posterioris latina I (1959), no. 19417
H. Walther, Proverbia sententiaeque latinitatis medii aevi, Carmina medii aevi posterioris latina II.5 (1967), no. 31566

signatures.p: Medieval alphanumeric leaf signatures in ink in the lower outer corner of many of the rectos in the first half of each quire in the form 'ai, aii, aiii, aiiii' etc., many probably lost to trimming due to the proximity of the remaining signatures to the edges of the leaves. The quires are signed a-i, k (j omitted).

catchwords.seg: Catchwords present in the lower margin of the last verso of each quire, sometimes enclosed in a simple scroll frame (e.g., f. 64v), or surrounded my small decorative flourishes (e.g., f. 24v).

supportDesc.condition: In good condition, some marginal annotations written in the inner margin partially obscured due to the tightness of the binding.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and lines, typically 40 lines to the page. Written below top line.

handNote.p: Folios 1r-77v (except for the poem 'Tres sunt stulticie ... nil metuaris') written in a gothic hybrida by a single scribe.

handDesc.handNote: Fragment of a poem ('Tres sunt stulticie ... nil metuaris') on f. 77v written in a semi-hybrida.

decoNote.p: Puzzle initial, 5 lines high, in red and blue at the opening of the text on f. 1r.
Plain initials in red, blue, or touched with yellow (see e.g., f. 29r) at the major and minor divisions of the text. Some initials touched with yellow.
Rubrication in plain red ink at the major and minor divisions of the text.
Paraph marks in red and blue.

note.p: Modern quire numbers added in pencil in Hindu-Arabic numerals in the lower outer corner of the first recto of each quire.

origin.origDate: Written in the late 14th or early 15th century.
origin.origPlace: Probably written somewhere in what is now Italy.

note.p: Date and place of production assigned based on palaeographical features.

acquisition.p: Folios 77v given to Corpus Christi College in 1574 by Matthew Parker (1504-1575) Parker, Matthew, 1504-1575, archbishop of Canterbury. It is possible that folios i-iv and v-viii were already bound with folios 1-77 at the time of Parker's gift to Corpus Christi College, particularly as a partially erased signiature with a distinctive flourish on f. viii recto also appears in simplified form on f. 77v; unfortunately, the name of the signator is unknown.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 412, ff. v-viii

note.p: Full transcription: Take euery day ix berys off yvy and brey them small and drynke them with warme watyr or ellys with whyÈt wyne grene or make powdyr alway the quantyte off ix kepte . Et ista medicina sedat dolorem et ardorem virgi solnit stranguiriam . Allso a noynt the yerd with oyle off rosys oftyntymys and inbybe blake wull in the seyde oyle and emplastre hytt a pon the yerd . allso the juse off purslan schall sese the ardoÈ of the yerd yff hit be anoyntyd therewith
Written in a late 16th century hand.
'Yerd' is a term for penis in Middle English.

listBibl.bibl: The three Middle English recipes are printed in IMEP XX, p. 121.

collation.p: Four endleaves (ff. v recto - viii verso)

signatures.p: No leaf signatures particular to this Part.
No quire signatures particular to this Part.

catchwords.seg: No catchwords particular to this Part.

supportDesc.condition: Generally in good condition. Adhesive residue on f. viii verso, suggestive of former use as a pastedown.

p.seg: Informally written, no ruling visible; written in single-column format.

handNote.p: Medical recipe on f. v recto written in an English hand with secretary features.

decoNote.p: Mostly erased sketch of a head in profile in ink on f. viii recto

note.p: An erased signature with a decorative flourish on f. viii recto. This signature also appears in simplified form on f. 77v, it is not possible to derive a name in either case.

origin.origDate: Recipe on f. v recto probably written in the 16th century.
origin.origPlace: England Recipe on f. v recto probably written in England

note.p: Date and place of production assigned based on palaeographical and linguistic features.
